question_stem: Suppose that the following simple linear regression model has been fitted to the Taiwan real estate data from topic 05. The model is Y = β₀ + β₁ ln(X₁) + e, where X₁ corresponds to distance to the nearest MRT. Which of the following is/are correct interpretations of the fitted equation: Ŷ = β̂₀ + β̂₁ ln(X₁)?
question_stem_html:
Suppose that the following simple linear regression model has been fitted to the Taiwan real estate data from topic 05:

Y=β0+β1ln(X1)+eY = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \ln(X_1) + e

where X₁ corresponds to distance to the nearest MRT.

Which of the following is/are correct interpretations of the fitted equation:

Y^=β0^+β1^ln(X1)\hat{Y} = \hat{\beta}_0 + \hat{\beta}_1 \ln(X_1)

choices.text: Every one unit increase in distance-to-MRT is associated with an average increase of β units in Y.
Every one unit increase in distance-to-MRT is associated with an average increase of β̂ units in Y.
Every doubling of distance-to-MRT is associated with an average increase of ln(2) × β̂ units in Y.
Every one unit increase in ln(X) is associated with an average increase of β̂ units in Y.

items.solution_html:
The correct interpretations are:

  • C — Every doubling of distance-to-MRT is associated with an average increase of ln(2) × β̂₁ units in Y.
  • D — Every one-unit increase in ln(X₁) is associated with an average increase of β̂₁ units in Y.
